Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Inferences on Cascadia Deformation Front and Plate Interface Properties from Advanced Studies of Active Source Seismic Data
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Cascadia subduction zone extends offshore western North America from northern California to British Columbia and has been the site of past great earthquakes comparable to the Tohoku Mw~9 earthquake in 2011. The last great earthquake at Cascadia occurred in 1700 and produced a trans-oceanic tsunami recorded in Japan. With estimated recurrence intervals of 300-500 yrs it represents a significant seismic and tsunami hazard for the dense coastal population of the Pacific Northwest. Furthering our understanding of the characteristics of this subduction zone is of significant societal interest. At present, Cascadia is unusually quiet seismically, with few of the frequent small earthquakes detected at most subduction zones, and the properties of this subduction zone are poorly understood. Furthermore, over 3 kilometers of sediment buries the Cascadia subduction fault or megathrust zone making it inaccessible to direct sampling. Marine seismic methods provide x-ray like images beneath the seafloor that can be used to illuminate the fault zone as well as constrain the properties of the fault and bounding sediments, which contribute to seismogenesis. This project will use previously acquired marine seismic data to investigate the structure of the Cascadia megathrust zone within the shallow portion where great earthquakes initiate. It will help elucidate properties of the fault zone in a region offshore central Oregon that may currently be creeping and which may act as a barrier to rupture in future earthquakes. This area will be compared with another region offshore Washington that is believed to be fully locked at present with potential for rupture over a larger area in future earthquakes. The understanding of megathrust properties obtained from the project will benefit other major ongoing and planned scientific programs in the region including studies of the subduction zone at central Oregon using NSF's Ocean Observatory Initiative and planned future subduction zone monitoring studies making use of the International Ocean Drilling Program. This study will support two graduate students and two early career scientists, helping to build the next generation of marine seismologists.

The project makes use of 8 km long-streamer multi-channel seismic and wide-angle ocean bottom seismometer data acquired in 2012 along two lines that cross the margin offshore central Oregon and Washington extending from ~40 km seaward of the deformation front to ~20 km from the coast, and one ~400 km line parallel to the coast located ~10-15 km seaward of the deformation front and spanning the 2 dip lines. The seismic data will be used for detailed studies of the properties of the basal sediment section and top oceanic crust near the Cascadia deformation front, including velocity-derived effective stress and pore fluid pressures, and for improved imaging of the forearc accretionary wedge within the Washington and Oregon regions of contrasting subduction zone properties. Sediment properties will be evaluated from compressional-wave velocity (Vp) models derived from Pre-Stack Depth Migration (PSDM) and Full Waveform Inversion, shear wave velocity (Vs) and splitting studies, and Amplitude vs Offset studies. Forearc accretionary wedge structure will be examined using PSDM imaging and waveform modeling of the plate interface. Specific project goals are: 1) to determine the seismic characteristics (Vp, Vs, Vp/Vs, anisotropy) and derived physical properties (porosity, effective stress, pore fluid pressure, and crack density) of the basal sediment section prior to subduction, and how these vary along the margin, and 2) to examine what conditions control the stratigraphic position of the proto-décollement and how these conditions are related to the different structural styles of the forearc and 3 to determine how the physical properties of plate interface zone at Cascadia vary in the down-dip direction both in the strongly-coupled Washington region as well as in the partially creeping central Oregon section, and how they relate to upper plate forearc deformation.

Institution.Name: Columbia University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: TRUSTEES OF COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY IN THE CITY OF NEW YORK, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Cascadia subduction zone extends offshore western North America from northern California to British Columbia and has been the site of past great earthquakes comparable to the Tohoku Mw~9 earthquake in 2011. The last great earthquake at Cascadia occurred in 1700 and produced a trans-oceanic tsunami recorded in Japan. With estimated earthquake recurrence intervals of 300-500 yrs Cascadia represents a significant seismic and tsunami hazard for the dense coastal population of the Pacific Northwest. Furthering our understanding of the characteristics of this subduction zone is of significant societal interest. This award supported advanced analysis of previously acquired marine seismic data which provide x-ray like images beneath the seafloor that illuminate the subduction megathrust as well as constrain the properties of the fault and overlying sediments, which contribute to earthquake initiation, size, and location. 

Cascadia is a sediment-rich subduction zone where the plate boundary fault or megathrust that forms as the downgoing Juan de Fuca (JdF) plate descends beneath North America is buried by over 3km of sediment at its shallowest depths. The properties of these sediments, including their density, how much water they contain, and their permeability, influence the slip behavior of the megathrust and how sediments deform within the offshore accretionary wedge that dominates the continental slope offshore Oregon and Washington.  Our project was conducted as a three institution collaborative effort and involved advanced analysis of marine multi-channel seismic reflection and ocean-bottom seismometerdata to characterize the properties of the basal sediments reaching to the Cascadia megathrust zone within the shallow portion where great earthquakes initiate. 

Primary activities supported by this award and our major findings include: 

Advanced AVO and sediment stratigraphy studies were conducted using seismic data acquired near the deformation front from central Oregon to Washington along the MARGIN transect (Figure 1). Prior studies of sediment properties along the Washington and Oregon transects indicates a stronger accretionary wedge offshore Washington, suggestive of higher tsunami potential than offshore central Oregon. One of the primary goals of the AVO and sediment stratigraphic analysis was to further investigate these along strike changes, which are closely linked to a change in the depth of decollement (or megathrust fault interface)  along the margin. Our results locate the change in wedge strength and decollement depth at 44?53?N, ~ 10 km south of and unrelated to the Daisey Bank strike-slip fault as in previous interpretations. These studies also provide further constraints on why a weaker wedge is present offshore Oregon, with downdip obstructions on the plate interface likely to account for the shallow megathrust in this region and presence of under-consolidated water rich sediments beneath the megathrust.Other findings from this study pertain to the markedly different internal stratigraphy of the Nitinat and Astoria fans and evidence for a underlying oceanic plate structural control on the confluence between these fans. 

Analysis of ocean-bottom seismometer data along transects crossing the JdF plate to the subduction zone was used to determine the velocity of sound and estimate the amount of water bound within this oceanic plate. We find evidence for little water in the downgoing JdF crust and upper most mantle near the deformation front offshore Washington consistent with previous findings based on lack of deep-reaching faults that could provide fluid pathways within this region where the plate bends into the subduction zone. We also find three time intervals of distinct crust and upper mantle structure on both Washington and Oregon transects that coincide with changes in the topography of basement  and spreading rate history. We attribute these coincident changes to differences in the mode of accretion at the paleo-JdF Ridge, with a shift at 6 Ma attributable to a change in JdF plate motion and one at ~4 Ma possibly related to hotspot proximity. The combined dataset indicates a spatially heterogeneous JdF plate with variable extents of hydration that result primarily from changes in crustal accretion and from differences in extent of faulting near the subduction zone. This heterogeneous structure predicts that the amount of water bound in the downgoing Juan de Fuca plate varies not only spatially along the margin but also at different times depending on the plate structure inherited from crustal formation.   

Broader Impacts of the study pertain to the improved understanding of megathrust properties which will benefit other major ongoing and planned scientific programs in the region including studies of the subduction zone at central Oregon using NSF's Ocean Observatory Initiative and planned future subduction zone monitoring studies making use of the International Ocean Drilling Program. Our component of the collaborative project has supported 1 graduate student, helping to build the next generation of marine seismologists. 

 


Last Modified: 07/09/2020
Modified by: Suzanne M Carbotte

Image
  • Properties of the sediment section along the MARGIN transect offshore central Oregon (left) to Washington (right). Results shown: Impedance Inversion (top), derived Density (middle) and delta Vp relative to Vp model for normally consolidated sediments. Green line-interpreted proto-decollement.
    Bridgit Boulahanis
    Copyrighted
    Suzanne M Carbotte
    Sediment properties along Cascadia Margin
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The Cascadia subduction zone extends offshore western North America from northern California to British Columbia and has been the site of past great earthquakes comparable to the Tohoku Mw~9 earthquake in 2011. The last great earthquake at Cascadia occurred in 1700 and produced a trans-oceanic tsunami recorded in Japan. With estimated earthquake recurrence intervals of 300-500 yrs Cascadia represents a significant seismic and tsunami hazard for the dense coastal population of the Pacific Northwest. Furthering our understanding of the characteristics of this subduction zone is of significant societal interest. This award supported advanced analysis of previously acquired marine seismic data which provide x-ray like images beneath the seafloor that illuminate the subduction megathrust as well as constrain the properties of the fault and overlying sediments, which contribute to earthquake initiation, size, and location. Cascadia is a sediment-rich subduction zone where the plate boundary fault or megathrust that forms as the downgoing Juan de Fuca (JdF) plate descends beneath North America is buried by over 3km of sediment at its shallowest depths. The properties of these sediments, including their density, how much water they contain, and their permeability, influence the slip behavior of the megathrust and how sediments deform within the offshore accretionary wedge that dominates the continental slope offshore Oregon and Washington. Our project was conducted as a three institution collaborative effort and involved advanced analysis of marine multi-channel seismic reflection and ocean-bottom seismometerdata to characterize the properties of the basal sediments reaching to the Cascadia megathrust zone within the shallow portion where great earthquakes initiate. Primary activities supported by this award and our major findings include: Advanced AVO and sediment stratigraphy studies were conducted using seismic data acquired near the deformation front from central Oregon to Washington along the MARGIN transect (Figure 1). Prior studies of sediment properties along the Washington and Oregon transects indicates a stronger accretionary wedge offshore Washington, suggestive of higher tsunami potential than offshore central Oregon. One of the primary goals of the AVO and sediment stratigraphic analysis was to further investigate these along strike changes, which are closely linked to a change in the depth of decollement (or megathrust fault interface) along the margin. Our results locate the change in wedge strength and decollement depth at 44?53?N, ~ 10 km south of and unrelated to the Daisey Bank strike-slip fault as in previous interpretations. These studies also provide further constraints on why a weaker wedge is present offshore Oregon, with downdip obstructions on the plate interface likely to account for the shallow megathrust in this region and presence of under-consolidated water rich sediments beneath the megathrust.Other findings from this study pertain to the markedly different internal stratigraphy of the Nitinat and Astoria fans and evidence for a underlying oceanic plate structural control on the confluence between these fans. Analysis of ocean-bottom seismometer data along transects crossing the JdF plate to the subduction zone was used to determine the velocity of sound and estimate the amount of water bound within this oceanic plate. We find evidence for little water in the downgoing JdF crust and upper most mantle near the deformation front offshore Washington consistent with previous findings based on lack of deep-reaching faults that could provide fluid pathways within this region where the plate bends into the subduction zone. We also find three time intervals of distinct crust and upper mantle structure on both Washington and Oregon transects that coincide with changes in the topography of basement and spreading rate history. We attribute these coincident changes to differences in the mode of accretion at the paleo-JdF Ridge, with a shift at 6 Ma attributable to a change in JdF plate motion and one at ~4 Ma possibly related to hotspot proximity. The combined dataset indicates a spatially heterogeneous JdF plate with variable extents of hydration that result primarily from changes in crustal accretion and from differences in extent of faulting near the subduction zone. This heterogeneous structure predicts that the amount of water bound in the downgoing Juan de Fuca plate varies not only spatially along the margin but also at different times depending on the plate structure inherited from crustal formation. Broader Impacts of the study pertain to the improved understanding of megathrust properties which will benefit other major ongoing and planned scientific programs in the region including studies of the subduction zone at central Oregon using NSF's Ocean Observatory Initiative and planned future subduction zone monitoring studies making use of the International Ocean Drilling Program. Our component of the collaborative project has supported 1 graduate student, helping to build the next generation of marine seismologists. Last Modified: 07/09/2020 Submitted by: Suzanne M Carbotte
